awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Developing Protein-based, Edible Coatings for Perishable Produce to Reduce Food Waste
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a sustainable coating technology to reduce global food waste and economic losses. Among all foods, fruits and vegetables are the highest categories of losses, with up to 50-60% of produce discarded in landfills. The proposed innovation will provide a desirable and healthy protein-fortified coating for food preservation and upcycle inexpensive food waste materials currently disposed of as landfills.  The coating is washable, edible, and glossy - providing an all-encompassing yet desirable food preservation solution that benefits consumers, sellers, and farmers alike. It extends the post-harvest life of perishable products by reducing maturation, senescence, dehydration, and microbial growth rates. The proposed coating technology will be targeted towards the growing food coating market and will offer significant potential to combat the challenge of food preservation and waste management effectively and simultaneously.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an eco-friendly and biodegradable protein-based nanocomposite coating that can be applied to the surface of perishable fruits and vegetables of any shape via dip and spray coatings.  Agro-derived proteins such as soy and corn will be modified by sequential chemical interactions using an optimized, bio-based plasticizer, crosslinker, and nanomaterials to fabricate the coating. In the preliminary work, cellulose nanocrystal-reinforced, egg-protein composite coating has significantly extended the shelf life and cosmetic appearance of various fruits, including banana, avocado, strawberry, and papaya. The coating has shown excellent antimicrobial properties and overcomes the significant challenge of simultaneously achieving the lowest oxygen and moisture barrier properties for a natural food coating. This combination of properties will extend the post-harvest life by reducing maturation, senescence, dehydration, and microbial growth rate. Future efforts include further optimizing materials, chemical modifications, scaling mechanisms from a technical perspective, and assessing business feasibility for potential commercialization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The EpiFresh team (#2319) participated in the New England Node National I-Corps summer cohort #2 in 2021. Our technology is an innovation of sustainable yet cost-effective coating that doubles the shelf-life of fresh produce and is sourced from low-cost, often wasted food materials. During the seven weeks of the I-Corps program, our team conducted 105 customer discovery interviews and found the experience to be extremely rewarding. After the seven weeks of the I-Corps program, we continued our customer discovery process and conducted more than 50 more customer discovery interviews both online and in-person. We were able to understand our stakeholders and customers as well as find the right product-market fit. Interviews included industry experts from each food value chain segment, including farmers, retailers, produce associations, and end-users. Through customer discovery, we were able to pinpoint the most significant pain point - low product turnover due to the low shelf-life of fruits and vegetables, especially organic produce. At first, we contacted local farmers; however, we soon learned that they generally do not sell to wholesalers and instead sell uncoated produce directly to end-users within a few days. The scale of waste was smaller than expected, and the need for a longer shelf-life was not as significant. During this time, we also understood the needs of retail store department managers and coating formulators. However, deciding who our right customers would be was challenging – whether it was the farmers, retailers, or coating formulators.

We pivoted our interviews towards focusing on large-scale growers that harvest, coat, and ship the perishable produce to large retailers. After several interviews, we understood that they deal with the billion-dollar pain point of low shelf-life and wastage. These growers carry a substantial financial burden because they must ensure that the product remains fresh when it reaches the retail distribution centers; otherwise, it gets rejected, and the growers suffer the costs. Since these growers work with low margins and may be risk-averse, we pivoted our focus on retail and corporate buyers as our customers since these buyers decide what produce should be in stores and influence the decisions of growers as well. Retail stores emphasized that they keep track of waste and rate their store performance based on D&D (damaged and destroyed) factors. As a result, not just the buyers at the top but every employee is motivated to reduce product waste, especially fresh produce. We understood from our interviews that these retailers deal with most waste and have an imperative need to increase product turnover. Our final business model would position us as a B2B packer and coating formulator that sells coated produce to these corporate buyers at retailers. We identified that there is a customer’s need, and the main value proposition was identified as doubling shelf-life leading to longer-lasting produce, and reducing shrinkage by 1%, whereas current shrinkage rates go up to 5%. Other value propositions included the non-waxy feel for consumers, a glossier appearance, and cost-effectiveness due to using low-cost, often wasted by-products from the food industry.

There is growing consumer interest and demand for affordable yet healthy and sustainable options for food products. From this consumer perspective, current commercial solutions for preserving fresh produce are limited as they pose environmental and long-term human health concerns. Our natural wax-alternative coating technology would provide a desirable, healthy protein-fortified food preservation product and innovatively upcycle inexpensive food waste materials, thereby significantly reducing commercial and valuable resource losses. Our simple technology would have the vital role of helping to reverse current significant commercial losses by providing more food and economic value to society with the existing food supply. Thus, food insecurity and hunger can be addressed through a sustainable, long-term approach.
